label: 278. Agreement between James B. Heyward and John Chadwick -- March 14, 1866
description: Article of agreement between James B. Heyward, William Henry Heyward and John Chadwick to replant Fife Plantation.  John Chadwick, from New York, agrees to provide $15,500 in capital for two-thirds share in the resulting rice crop.  4p. March 14, 1866.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Article of agreement between James B. Heyward, William Henry Heyward and John Chadwick to replant Fife Plantation.  John Chadwick, from New York, agrees to provide $15,500 in capital for two-thirds share in the resulting rice crop.  4p. March 14, 1866.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: Articles of Agreement made this fourteenth day of March One thousand eight hundred and sixty six, between John Chadwick of the City and State of New York of the first part, William Henry Heyward of the second part, and James B. Heyward of the third part. Whereas the said parties are desirous of cultivating a plantation known by the name of Fife, situate lying and being on Savannah Back river in Beaufort District in the State of South Carolina for the term and subject to the stipulations hereinafter expressed. Now these presents witness that each of the said parties for himself his heirs executors and administrators covenants with the others of them their Executors and Administrators in manner and form following that is to say. The said parties of the second and third parts agree to contribute the use of the said plantation known as Fife for the term of this agreement free of any rent. The said part of the first part agrees to advance Fifteen thousand five hundred dollars if so much be necessary and if so much be not necessary then a sum sufficient to prepare stock pay wages of laborers and of an overseer to cultivate the said plantation in rice and it is agreed that if more than three hundred acres are planted the said party of the first part will advance an additional sum proportionate to the number of additional acres so planted. It is further agreed between the parties [End Page 1] that the money so advanced shall only be drawn for by the party of the second part by Drafts on Cohen Hankel & Co Factors doing business in Charleston in such sums and as such times as it may be necessary for the use of the said plantation. It is also agreed that Wm. Henry Heyward the party of the second part is to have the sole control and management of the said plantation the supervision and control of overseers and of hands and the governing directing and discharging of the same and also the sole management of the details of the crop and the preparing and sending the same to market and the said Wm. Henry Heyward binds himself to give his time and attention to the control and management of the said plantation. The party of the first part agrees to pay in addition to the advance made for the use of the plantation the sum of Fifteen hundred dollars per annum to the said Wm Henry Heyward for his personal services and supervision in the cultivation of three hundred acres, but if more than three hundred acres are planted then he agrees to pay to the said party of the second part an additional sum of money proportioned to the additional number of acres planted. It is further agreed between the parties that out of the year's crop the money [End Page 2] advanced by the party of the first part exclusive of the sum paid to the party of the second part for his services in supervising shall first be refunded to the said party of the first part, and after such refunding the net proceeds of the crop are to be divided as follows; two thirds of the same to be the share of the party of the first part and one third to be the share of the parties of the second and third parts jointly and at the termination of this agreement the same division in the same proportion is to be made of all lumber agricultural implements mules mule feed, flats seed rice and all other stock of whatsoever kind that may be remaining on the said plantation. It is also agreed and the said party of the second part hereby binds himself that the crop as soon as it can be gotten ready for market shall be sent to Cohen Hankel & Co Commission Merchants and Factors in Charleston for sale during the continuance of this agreement and the said Cohen Hanckel & Co are hereby authorized to pay to the said parties his and their share of the proceeds as in the clause last above of this agreement provided. It is further agreed that this agreement shall continue in force for the term of one year notwithstanding the death of any of the parties and shall be further continued on the same terms [End Page 3] for the additional term of two years provided that at or before the end of the first year none of the parties shall signify his dissent to the same. In case of the death of Wm Henry Heyward during the continuance of this agreement it is agreed that the surviving parties shall together with the Executor or executors or Administrator of the said Wm Henry Heyward or in case that none shall have qualified then with the eldest surviving son of the said Wm Henry Heyward agree as to the appointment of a suitable person to manage the said plantation in the place of the said Wm Henry Heyward which person shall receive the same salary as is provided by this agreement to be paid to the said Wm Henry Heyward but in case the said parties cannot agree then the matter shall be referred to three persons one appointed by each of the said parties and a majority of the said persons so appointed shall appoint a suitable person to supervise and their decision shall be binding on the parties their heirs executors and administrators. Witness our hands and seals the day and year first above written Jn Chadwick Wm Henry Heyward Jas. B. Heyward Witness to Signatures of J. C and WHH [illegible] J. Thompson to signature of J.B H W H Simmons. [End Page 4]
